the_san_francisco_mint: Completed in 1874, the Old San Francisco Mint was designed by Alfred B. Mullett in the Greek Revival style. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))

Nicknamed 'The Granite Lady,' the building is primarily constructed of sandstone from Newcastle Island, British Columbia. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_San_Francisco_Mint?utm_source=openai))

During the 1906 earthquake, Superintendent Frank A. Leach and his staff protected $300 million in gold reserves, about one-third of the nation's holdings. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))

The Mint's enclosed central courtyard with a well helped it survive the 1906 fires. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))

After the 1906 disaster, the Mint served as a temporary bank, aiding San Francisco's recovery. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))

In 2003, the federal government sold the Old Mint to San Francisco for a symbolic 1879 silver dollar. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/S-F-ready-to-mint-SoMa-museum-City-buys-2598203.php?utm_source=openai))
The building was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1961. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))
The Old Mint is located at 88 5th Street, San Francisco, CA 94103. ([thesanfranciscomint.com](https://thesanfranciscomint.com/info/?utm_source=openai))

The Mint's design includes a central pedimented portico flanked by projecting wings in an E-shape. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))

The building's foundation was designed to prevent tunneling into its vaults. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))
The Old Mint housed a museum from 1973 to 1994. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))
The building's restoration began in 1972 and was completed in 1976. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))

The Old Mint is one of the few buildings that survived the 1906 earthquake and fire. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))
The building's exterior features six colossal columns on the portico. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))
The Old Mint was designated a California Historical Landmark in 1974. ([home.treasury.gov](https://home.treasury.gov/about/history/curator/us-mint-buildings/san-francisco-mint?utm_source=openai))
lotta's_fountain: Lotta Crabtree, a famed vaudeville performer, gifted the fountain in 1875. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotta%27s_Fountain?utm_source=openai))
The fountain became a crucial meeting point after the 1906 earthquake. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotta%27s_Fountain?utm_source=openai))
Opera singer Luisa Tetrazzini performed there for 250,000 people in 1910. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotta%27s_Fountain?utm_source=openai))

Originally 24 feet tall, it was raised to 32 feet in 1916. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/Life-for-Lotta-s-Fountain-A-spurt-of-promises-3330040.php?utm_source=openai))
The fountain was restored to its original height in 1999. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotta%27s_Fountain?utm_source=openai))
Annual earthquake commemorations are held there every April 18 at 5:12 a.m. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotta%27s_Fountain?utm_source=openai))
In 2023, a cast iron flower adornment was stolen from the fountain. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/lottas-fountain-san-francisco-vandalized-18254436.php?utm_source=openai))
The fountain features lion's-head spigots and griffin-head basins. ([theclio.com](https://theclio.com/entry/15232?utm_source=openai))

It was cast in Philadelphia and shipped around Cape Horn to San Francisco. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Lotta-s-Legacy-Lives-123-year-old-S-F-fountain-2975946.php?utm_source=openai))
Lotta Crabtree danced on barrels in saloons during the Gold Rush era. ([atlasobscura.com](https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/lotta-s-fountain?utm_source=openai))
The fountain was relocated slightly during Market Street renovations in 1974. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotta%27s_Fountain?utm_source=openai))
In 1954, a drunk driver nearly destroyed the fountain in a collision. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Lotta-s-Legacy-Lives-123-year-old-S-F-fountain-2975946.php?utm_source=openai))
The fountain's water was turned off during the 1975 drought. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Lotta-s-Legacy-Lives-123-year-old-S-F-fountain-2975946.php?utm_source=openai))
A bronze relief of Luisa Tetrazzini commemorates her 1910 performance. ([theclio.com](https://theclio.com/entry/15232?utm_source=openai))
The fountain is one of San Francisco's oldest surviving monuments. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotta%27s_Fountain?utm_source=openai))
old_saint_mary's_cathedral: Cornerstone laid on July 17, 1853, by Bishop Joseph S. Alemany.
Built using Chinese granite and New England bricks.
Designed in Gothic Revival style by Craine & England.
Served as San Francisco's first cathedral until 1891.
Clock face inscription warns against vice: 'Son, Observe the Time and Fly from Evil.'
Emperor Norton collapsed nearby in 1880 en route to a lecture.
Survived 1906 earthquake; gutted by subsequent fire.
Rebuilt in 1909 under architect Willis Polk.
Hosted events for 450,000 WWII servicemen and women.
Located at 660 California Street, San Francisco.
tin_how_temple: Founded circa 1852, Tin How Temple is the oldest Taoist temple in San Francisco's Chinatown. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))
Dedicated to Mazu, the Chinese sea goddess known as Tin How in Cantonese. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))
Original temple destroyed in 1906 earthquake; rebuilt in 1910 at 125 Waverly Place. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))
Temple closed in 1955; reopened on May 4, 1975, after Chinatown's rejuvenation. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))
In 2010, celebrated 100th anniversary with a religious procession, dances, and fireworks. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))
Waverly Place is known in Chinese as 'Tin How Temple Street' due to the temple's significance. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))
Temple is located on the top floor of a four-story building at 125 Waverly Place. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))

Visitors must climb three flights of stairs to reach the temple. ([lonelyplanet.com](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco/north-beach-and-chinatown/attractions/tin-how-temple/a/poi-sig/384111/1329641?utm_source=openai))

Photography is not allowed inside the temple to preserve its sanctity. ([lonelyplanet.com](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco/north-beach-and-chinatown/attractions/tin-how-temple/a/poi-sig/384111/1329641?utm_source=openai))

Temple's altar miraculously survived the 1906 earthquake and fire. ([lonelyplanet.com](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco/north-beach-and-chinatown/attractions/tin-how-temple/a/poi-sig/384111/1329641?utm_source=openai))
The temple is a significant landmark in Chinatown, reflecting the community's resilience. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_How_Temple?utm_source=openai))
Tin How Temple is considered a must-visit for tourists to San Francisco. ([chinatownology.com](https://chinatownology.com/tin_how_temple.html?utm_source=openai))
cable_car_museum: Established in 1974, the museum is housed in the historic Washington/Mason cable car barn and powerhouse. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
Visitors can observe the massive engines and winding wheels that pull the cables. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))

The museum displays three antique cable cars from the 1870s, including the only surviving car from the first cable car company. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
Exhibits include grips, track, brake mechanisms, tools, and detailed models. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
A viewing area allows visitors to see the large sheaves and cable lines entering the building. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
The museum store offers cable car memorabilia, books, clothing, and genuine cable car bells. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
Located at 1201 Mason Street, the museum is open daily with free admission. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
The museum is operated by the Friends of the Cable Car Museum, a nonprofit organization. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
The museum's main level is wheelchair accessible via a separate entrance. ([cablecarmuseum.org](https://www.cablecarmuseum.org/museum.html?utm_source=openai))
The museum is part of the complex that houses the cable car powerhouse and car depot. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Cable_Car_Museum?utm_source=openai))

The museum's mezzanine offers a subterranean glimpse beneath the city streets of the cables, sheaves, gears, and electric motors that run the system. ([atlasobscura.com](https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/san-francisco-cable-car-museum?utm_source=openai))
The museum is located in the Nob Hill neighborhood of San Francisco. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Cable_Car_Museum?utm_source=openai))
The museum is a free museum in the Nob Hill neighborhood of San Francisco, California. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Cable_Car_Museum?utm_source=openai))

The museum is open from 10 AM to 6 PM between April 1 and September 30 and from 10 AM to 5 PM between October 1 and March 31, apart from some public holidays. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Cable_Car_Museum?utm_source=openai))
The museum is run by the Friends of the Cable Car Museum. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_Cable_Car_Museum?utm_source=openai))
portsmouth_square_park: Captain John B. Montgomery raised the American flag here on July 9, 1846. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
Sam Brannan announced the Gold Rush at this plaza on May 11, 1848. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
California's first public school was built on the square's southwest corner in 1847. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
The square served as a refuge after the 1906 earthquake and fire. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
Robert Louis Stevenson frequented the square during his 1879-1880 visit. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
The first cable car rolled past the square in 1873. ([kqed.org](https://www.kqed.org/news/11787679/the-rich-history-of-san-franciscos-first-plaza?utm_source=openai))
A citizens' assembly organized against 'The Hounds' on July 16, 1849. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
Memorial services for President Zachary Taylor were held here on August 29, 1850. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
The square hosted the first Admission Day celebration on October 29, 1850. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
A protest against purchasing the Jenny Lind Theatre occurred here on June 1, 1852. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
Colonel E.D. Baker delivered an oration for Senator David C. Broderick here in 1859. ([ohp.parks.ca.gov](https://ohp.parks.ca.gov/ListedResources/Detail/119?utm_source=openai))
The square is known as the 'Heart of Chinatown.' ([sfrecpark.org](https://sfrecpark.org/893/Portsmouth-Square?utm_source=openai))
A statue of the Goddess of Democracy commemorates the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portsmouth_Square?utm_source=openai))
The Portsmouth Square pedestrian bridge is a renowned skateboarding spot. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portsmouth_Square_pedestrian_bridge?utm_source=openai))
The square was the site of San Francisco's first City Hall. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Changes-could-be-in-store-Portsmouth-Square-11106856.php?utm_source=openai))
jackson_square: Jackson Square, established during the 1849 Gold Rush, became San Francisco's first commercial district. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_Square%2C_San_Francisco?utm_source=openai))
The area was part of the notorious Barbary Coast, known for its saloons and brothels. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_Square%2C_San_Francisco?utm_source=openai))

Many buildings in Jackson Square survived the 1906 earthquake and fire, preserving 19th-century architecture. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_Square%2C_San_Francisco?utm_source=openai))

Domenico Ghirardelli operated his first chocolate factory here in 1853 before moving to Ghirardelli Square. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/travel/article/Jackson-Square-an-example-an-S-F-survivor-7462103.php?utm_source=openai))
The Hotaling Building, built in 1866, was saved from the 1906 fire by a mile-long fire hose. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotaling_Building?utm_source=openai))
Hotaling Place, San Francisco's oldest alley, was once on the city's original shoreline. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_Square%2C_San_Francisco?utm_source=openai))
The Old Ship Saloon, established in 1851, operated from a ship's hull buried beneath the streets. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))

The Bank of Lucas, Turner & Co., built in 1853, was managed by future General William Tecumseh Sherman. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Lucas%2C_Turner_%26_Co.?utm_source=openai))
The Fugazi Bank Building, constructed in 1909, is a notable example of Classical Revival architecture. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fugazi_Bank_Building?utm_source=openai))

Jackson Square's architecture features brick buildings with cast-iron shutters, reflecting its Gold Rush heritage. ([citiesandparks.com](https://citiesandparks.com/ca/jackson-square-sf/?utm_source=openai))

The area transformed from a red-light district to a hub for art galleries and antique shops in the 1950s. ([untappedcities.com](https://www.untappedcities.com/from-the-barbary-coast-to-jackson-square-an-historic-neighborhood-transformed/?utm_source=openai))

Jackson Square is part of the Barbary Coast Trail, a 3.8-mile walking tour of historic sites. ([sfgate.com](https://www.sfgate.com/travel/article/Jackson-Square-an-example-an-S-F-survivor-7462103.php?utm_source=openai))

The Transamerica Pyramid, completed in 1972, now towers over the historic Jackson Square neighborhood. ([sfmta.com](https://www.sfmta.com/blog/history-stroll-winter-jackson-square-gold-rush-days-modern-times?utm_source=openai))

Jackson Square's narrow, tree-lined streets and historic buildings attract luxury boutiques and restaurants. ([forbes.com](https://www.forbes.com/sites/kristenphilipkoski/2016/11/21/san-franciscos-buzziest-new-luxury-shopping-destination-jackson-square/?utm_source=openai))

The neighborhood's blend of history and modernity makes it a unique San Francisco destination. ([sftravel.com](https://www.sftravel.com/article/your-guide-to-san-franciscos-jackson-square?utm_source=openai))
the_old_ship_saloon: In 1849, the ship Arkansas ran aground on Alcatraz Island. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
Towed to Yerba Buena Cove, it became the Old Ship Alehouse in 1851. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
A hole was cut in the bow to serve as the entrance. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
Sign read: 'Gude, Bad, an Indif'rent Spirits Sold Here! At 25¢ each'. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
Bartender James 'Jimmy' Laflin was a notorious shanghaier. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
By 1855, the cove was filled in, leaving the ship landlocked. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
In 1859, a hotel was built atop the buried ship's remains. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
The 1906 earthquake destroyed the building; rebuilt in 1907. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))
In 2016, construction unearthed parts of the Arkansas's hull. ([projects.sfsujournalism.org](https://projects.sfsujournalism.org/877/uncategorized/hoppy-history/?utm_source=openai))
The Old Ship Saloon is a stop on the Barbary Coast Trail. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Old_Ship_Saloon?utm_source=openai))

Located at 298 Pacific Ave, it's San Francisco's oldest bar. ([sfchronicle.com](https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Old-Ship-Saloon-lives-on-thanks-to-new-owners-10917992.php?utm_source=openai))
The saloon's sign is a replica of the original ship. ([7x7.com](https://www.7x7.com/oldest-bars-2671645223.html?utm_source=openai))
The bar survived Prohibition by changing ownership and name. ([projects.sfsujournalism.org](https://projects.sfsujournalism.org/877/uncategorized/hoppy-history/?utm_source=openai))
In 2017, new owners preserved its historic legacy. ([sfchronicle.com](https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Old-Ship-Saloon-lives-on-thanks-to-new-owners-10917992.php?utm_source=openai))
The saloon has operated continuously for over 170 years. ([projects.sfsujournalism.org](https://projects.sfsujournalism.org/877/uncategorized/hoppy-history/?utm_source=openai))
